text:
Tomcat4 b7 seems unwilling to reload changed supporting classes from disk.

1. reloadable="true" is set for the context in server.xml.
2. Alterations to a JSP page results in a recompilation & reloading of the 
generated class as expected.
3. Alterations to supporting classes do not cause a reloading.  Deletion of the 
actual '.class' file being referenced by the <%@page import =""%> results in a 
new compilation from the source '.java', but this newly compiled class is not 
loaded - rather the old one remains.
4. Supporting class in question is in the WEB-INF/classes/ directory beneath 
the JSP being executed. (which is not on the classpath)

Rolling back to tomcat 3.2.3 & using exactly the same testing methodology 
resulted in the changed supporting class being reloaded.
creator: matthew.firth@anu.edu.au

text:
Could you provide a small web application that illustrates this problem?  This
facility works fine for me, as long as I wait for the number of seconds between
checks for modified classes (defaults to 15 seconds).

A couple of things to double check:

* Including a class in a <@% page import="..." %> directive does *not*
  cause the corresponding class to be loaded unless the JSP page is
  actually compiled.

* Tomcat does *not* monitor changes to the "xxx.java" source file for
  a support class.  You must recompile it yourself -- Tomcat is watching
  the actual "xxx.class" files for changes.

* If you modify a class that has never been loaded, no reload will be
  triggered because it is unnecessary.
creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
